definition[0]: to tell someone officially that something they have done is very wrong
example[0]: The military court reprimanded him for failing to do his duty.
definition[1]: to tell someone that they have done something wrong or illegal and are being punished for it â€“ used especially in official contexts
example[1]: The police officers were officially reprimanded for their behaviour.
example[2]: The Swiss authorities severely reprimanded the banks for accepting $660 million from the former Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha.
example[3]: Debra remembered as a very young child being reprimanded by her father.
definition[2]: if a parent, teacher, or other adult scolds a child, they talk to them angrily because they have done something wrong. Scold sounds rather formal and old-fashioned. In everyday English people usually say tell somebody off
example[4]: I dreaded the thought of going home and being scolded by my father.
definition[3]: to talk angrily to someone because they have done something wrong. Tell somebody off is more common in British English than American English
example[5]: Dad told me off for getting home late.
definition[4]: to talk angrily to a child because they have done something wrong
example[6]: The boy was given a good talking-to and sent home.
definition[5]: to talk angrily to someone for a long time about something they have done wrong, especially in a way that they think is not necessary or fair
example[8]: He began to lecture her about her duties as a citizen.
definition[6]: to tell someone that they should not have done something
example[9]: She rebuked him for being late.
example[10]: Sheerman rebuked his colleague for suggesting that he was too stupid to understand what he was saying.
definition[7]: to talk to someone in a way that shows you are disappointed at what they have done. Reproach  sounds much gentler than criticizing someone or reprimanding them
example[11]: He felt he had to reproach his friend for his excessive drinking.
definition[8]: to publicly criticize someone for a long time, in a way that shows you strongly disapprove of what they have done
example[12]: She berated the paper for its 'misleading front-page story.'
example[13]: Kennedy berated the Eisenhower administration and its vice president Richard Nixon, during the 1960 campaign.
definition[9]: an occasion when someone is officially told that they have done something very wrong
example[14]: He is likely to receive some kind of reprimand for trying to influence the regulators unfairly.
